Issues.Title: Provide InjectionToken with factory provider in a component level
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Today, if you want to provide something with a factory provider in a component level, you have to separately create the InjectionToken and the factory function like so:

```ts
const TOKEN = new InjectionToken('my token');

...
{
  provide: TOKEN,
  useFactory: () => ... 
}
```

If you want to provide the value in root, you have a better option:

```ts
const TOKEN = new InjectionToken('my token', {
  factory: () => ...
});
```

Why is this better? 
* You have type inference for the factory value
* Your logic is encapsulated. This token knows how its value is defined and does not need to trust consumers to provide the value properly + your factory function is not exposed and cannot be used elsewhere. 
* You can instantly start using this token without needing to set up anything else / create any other kind of boilerplate code. 

Unfortunately, if you want this token to be provided in a component level, and not the root level, you can't do that. As angular's component "providers" property does not allow for InjectionTokens.

### Proposed solution

Support passing an injection token in the "providers" array of a component (and module). If this token defines its own factory - it should be used. If not - a runtime exception should be thrown. It's better if we could even type the injection token differently, so only ones that define their factory can be used. 

### Alternatives considered

Use the "FactoryProvider" syntax, which is less ideal based on what I described above. 

I'm willing to try to implement this myself, if someone with more experience with the Angular source code can point me in the right direction.

Issues.Title: (input) event does not fire in Firefox under certain conditions
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms, Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When building a custom `ControlValueAcessor` implementation that builds upon an exsting `ControlValueAcessor` implementation, the `(input)` event of the underlying `<input>` field does not fire under certain conditions.
There's a lot that needs to happen for this bug to appear but I'll try my best to explain.

There needs to be an implementation of `ControlValueAcessor` that contains an `<input>` field. This input fields needs to transmit the value via a `[value]` binding and `(input)` event. It also needs to have a `(keydown)` event.
I'll call this implementation the child `ControlValueAcessor`.

Now you need to have a second implementation of `ControlValueAcessor` that uses the child `ControlValueAcessor` in combinations with an `[(ngModel)]` binding and `(ngModelChange)` event.
This second implementation then needs to be defined as a `FormControl` in a `FormGroup`.
The `FormControl` needs to have an error in the `errors` attribute.

You now need to have a third component that takes the `errors` from the `FormControl` and renders them in an HTML element with `display: block`.

If all conditions are met then the user is no longer able to enter anything into the `<input>` field. However, spamming the keys on my keyboard did work and I was able to get some characters to appear in the `<input>` field.

I used Firefox 113.0 (32-bit) and Firefox Developer Edition 110.0b9 (64-bit) to test the bug.
I also used Chrome 113.0.5672.93 to test it.
As far as I can tell, this bug only affects Firefox (both editions).

I unfortunately couldn't get a Stackblitz to run but I will link a GitHub repository with the code used to produce the bug.

If anybody else experiences this bug (which I doubt) there is a workaround as far as I've found.
In the component that renders the `errors` you just have to implement `OnChanges` with `SimpleChanges` and do a deep copy of the `errors` to a local variable and use that to render. You could also not use `display: block`.

Issues.Title: ng serve with esbuild does not deliver assets when project directory contains URL-encoded entity
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I stumbled upon this issue in a project with a space in its name on the repository server (when cloning via HTTPS, the "%20" from the checkout URL remains part of the workspace directory name). This sure isn't ideal, but everything works, except for serving assets (i.e., favicon, _assets_ folder) with the esbuild builder for ng serve: The assets are not served and will instead return 404.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. `mkdir repo%20sitory`
1. `cd repo%20sitory`
1. `ng new app`
1. `cd app`
1. (change _angular.json_ to include esbuild builder)
1. `ng serve`
1. _favicon.ico_ will 404

Renaming `repo%20sitory` to `repository` fixes the issue.

### Exception or Error

```text
All assets are not served, and requests will return a 404 error response. They are copied properly when running `ng build` though.
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 16.0.1
Node: 16.18.1
Package Manager: npm 8.19.2
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 16.0.1
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1600.1
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.0.1
@angular-devkit/core            16.0.1
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.0.1
@schematics/angular             16.0.1
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.0.4
```

(Also happens on Windows.)

### Anything else relevant?

The `%20` is URL-decoded somewhere along the line: The server will even attempt to load the file from the (URL-decoded) `repo sitory` directory in the file system until vite jumps in and disallows serving this file from outside the project folder, resulting in a 403 error response.

### Description

I searched through the issues and I did found some related issues but they weren't exactly the same:

- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/23448
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/10624

Feel free to close this issue if you fill like it's a duplicate of another one.

I wanted to update my angular project to the latest version and I executed the command:

```shell
ng update @angular/cli @angular/core
```

In my project I have as a development dependency `@types/web` (TypeScript DOM declaration files) because I have private libraries that use my applications and I like to make sure that all my projects use the same version of declaration files and also I like to decouple the TypeScript compiler version from the declaration files version.

The dependecy in the `package.json` looks like the following:

```
"@typescript/lib-dom": "npm:@types/web@^0.0.99"
```

You can see that the package hosted in NPM registry is `@types/web` but the name of the dependency store in `node_modules` is `@typescript/lib-dom`.  

It's this way because TypeScript will search in `/node_modules/@typescript/lib-dom` to know if the declaration files have been installed independently. If the folder is not present, it will use the declaration files that come with the TypeScript compiler (`/node_modules/typescript/lib/lib.dom.d.ts`).

When I execute the `ng update` command, I get the following error:

```shell
✔ Packages successfully installed.
Using package manager: npm
Collecting installed dependencies...
Found 16 dependencies.
Fetching dependency metadata from registry...
✖ Migration failed: 404 Not Found - GET https://registry.npmjs.org/@typescript%2flib-dom - Not found
  See ".../angular-errors.log" for further details.
```

Basically, the Angular CLI is trying to fetch `@typescript/lib-dom` but this is not the name of the package, the correct name to fetch is `@types/web`.

Issues.Title: `valueChange` Event in v16.0.0 No Longer Emits Values Continuously During Slider Drag
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [x] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

15.1.0

### Description

In version 15.1.0, the `valueChange` event used with `matSliderThumb` would emit values continuously as the slider was being dragged. This was particularly useful for updating values in real-time during a drag operation. For instance, consider the following setup:

```html
<mat-slider>
  <input
    (dragStart)="dragSliderStartMin(index)"
    (valueChange)="minSliderValueChange($event, index)"
    matSliderStartThumb
  />
  <input
    (dragStart)="dragSliderStartMax(index)"
    (valueChange)="maxSliderValueChange($event, index)"
    matSliderEndThumb
  />
</mat-slider>
```

```ts
async dragSliderStartMin(index: number) {
  await this.loadFile(i);
}

minSliderValueChange(value: number, index: number) {
  // ...
}

// ...
```

However, in the newly released v16.0.0, this behavior appears to have changed. The `valueChange` event only emits a value when the slider dragging operation ends, as opposed to continuously during the drag.

To restore the previous behavior, one workaround I found is using `ngModel` for template-driven binding:
```html
<mat-slider>
  <input
    [(ngModel)]="sliderValue"
    (ngModelChange)="sliderValueChange($event)"
    matSliderThumb
  />
</mat-slider>
```

Alternatively, I achieved the same result by using `formControl` with reactive forms and subscribing to `valueChange`:
```html
<mat-slider>
  <input
    (dragStart)="dragSliderStartMin(index)"
    [formControl]="expectationMin($event, index)"
    matSliderStartThumb
  />
  <input
    (dragStart)="dragSliderStartMax(index)"
    [formControl]="expectationMax($event, index)"
    matSliderEndThumb
  />
</mat-slider>
```
```ts

ngOnInit() {
  this.addSubscriptions();
}

addSubscriptions() {
  this.expectationMin(this.index)
    .valueChanges.pipe(distinctUntilChanged())
    .subscribe((value) => {
      console.log('min value changed', value);
      this.minSliderValueChange(value, this.index);
    });

  // same for expectationMax and maxSliderValueChange
}
```

I wanted to bring up this change in behavior as it may impact other users who relied on the continuous value emission during slider drags in their projects. Can anyone confirm if this change was intentional or if it's a bug?

### Reproduction

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Reproduction of the issue in Angular v16.0.0

Navigate to the StackBlitz sample code for Angular v16.0.0: [Angular 16 slider with valueChanges showing value only when drag ends](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-16-material-starter-xdmmkz?file=package.json).

In this sample, notice that when you drag the slider, the value changes are only displayed when the dragging ends. This is the behavior we're discussing in this issue.

2. Comparison with the behavior in Angular v15.1.0

Now, navigate to the StackBlitz sample code for Angular v15.1.0: [Angular 15, same source code, slider with valueChanges showing value when dragging the slider](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-16-material-starter-fmmekv?file=package.json).

In this sample, when you drag the slider, the value changes are continuously displayed next to the slider as you're dragging. This is the previous behavior we're comparing to.

By observing the behavior in both versions of Angular with the same source code, you can clearly see the difference in valueChange event emissions during slider dragging.

### Expected Behavior

In Angular Material version 15.1.0, the `valueChange` event used with `matSliderThumb` was designed to emit values continuously as the slider was being dragged. This enabled real-time value updates during a drag operation. I expect to see this same behavior in Angular Material version 16.0.0.

### Actual Behavior

In Angular Material version 16.0.0, the `valueChange` event's behavior appears to have changed. Instead of emitting values continuously during the slider dragging operation, it now only emits a value when the slider drag operation ends. This change interrupts real-time value updates and only allows for updates when the user releases the slider.

- CDK/Material: 16.0.0
- Browser(s): Version 113.0.5672.92 (Official Build) (arm64)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs Ventura, Version 13.3.1
